subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Group
msgSnippet: Hey, everyone, I m still here.  Paige, now how can you forget a last name like Zuck.  It s as American as apple pie.  (Er, as German as Bratwurst!)  Seriously,
messageBody:
Hey, everyone, I'm still here.  Paige, now how can you forget a last name like Zuck.  It's as American as apple pie.  (Er, as German as Bratwurst!)  Seriously, it's nice to see the Alphabet generating some discussion again.. I'm still interested in crazy writing systems, and but have been mostly studying shorthands...Regarding the problems with the Jerome font, I still don't know why in some applications the cursor behaves so strangely. 
 
 
 
Shalom v'Tovah,
 
Jon  
http://surf.to/frimmin
 
It is more necessary to love much than to think much;
always do that which impels you most to love.
 
        --St. Teresa of Avila, The Interior Castle
----- Original Message -----
From: Paige Gabhart
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, February 13, 2002 8:19 PM
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Group

Ed:
 
Thanks for your e-mail.  I have attached a response in Read's Alphabet to your attachment.  Hope you have fun reading it. My computer insisted in saving it in Word 6.0.  I am not a Word user myself so I hope this does not cause you a problem in viewing the file.
 
I'll talk about which characters need work when I have a little more time.  Jon (last name escapes me at the moment, but he lives in Virginia, USA) put Jerome together, and my understanding is it was a first attempt on his part to work with fonts so my hat is off to him.   I haven't heard anything from him in quite some time, but he is still listed as a member of the group.  When Jon uploaded Jerome, I was ecstatic.  I had tried to interest someone in the Shavian group  in designing a Quikscript font, but no one seemed interested.  It was so cool to be able to type in Quikscript (I still prefer this name, although I acquiesced in calling this group Read_Alphabet to give recognition to Kingsley Read.)  after years of being the only person I knew who was still using it.
 
I corresponded with Sidney briefly years ago.  (Aside:  Sidney & Jon, I must apologize to both of you for not responding to your letters last year.  I was so busy at the time, I never got to them despite my good intentions.)  It is gratifying to see that he too has maintained his interest after so long a time.

 

 

Paige Gabhart
----- Original Message -----
From: Ed Gaddy
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, February 13, 2002 12:00 AM
Subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Group

Hi,

 

Im new to this group and thought perhaps its activity had died down. So it was good to hear from both Sidney and Paige.

 

Ive kept a very simple journal in Quikscript off and on for some time. Im hoping that some correspondence in Quikscript will improve my skills a bit and give me a feel for a better way to write in English.

 

In response to some of Paiges comments, I have fooled around making some very crude computer fonts using an inexpensive program called Font Creator Program (FCP). With this program, Ive had difficulty designing the characters so that the cursor went to its intended and usual position. Perhaps this is what ails Jerome.

 

Paige, can you tell me which characters you think are malformed? I could have a go at improving them - - - but please do not get your hopes very high. Whoever made Jerome is better at making fonts than I am.

 

If anyone would care to, Id like to carry on some short, simple, correspondence in Quikscript. So as a start, Ive attached a Word document with a couple of sentences in Quikscript using Jerome. Despite Paiges comments, I cant even read my own Quikscript with Jerome unless I keep the characters from running together. I do this by going to Words

 

Format/Font/Character Spacing/Spacing menu and expanding by about 1.2 points.

 

 

 

Best Wishes,

 

 

e-mail: ed.gaddy@...

phone:  301 390 5115

 

-----Original Message-----
From: Sidney Tanaban [mailto:sidban2@...]
Sent: Monday, February 11, 2002 6:59 PM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Group

 

Hi
I saw your message.  I know both Shaws and Kwikskript but have not seen any Kwikskrit on internet.  I would appreciate you letting me know if there is.  Like you I have not had much opportunity to read it and that is as important as writing it.  One way is by letter and I tried somewhat to promote that but no one was interested.  Like you I am not software savvy and have no idea how to make up a page for Kwikskript.  Please keep in touch if anyone is capable of doing something in this area.

Sid


On Mon, 11 February 2002, "pgabhart" wrote:

>
> Welcome to all new members of the group and hello again to those who
> have been members for awhile.  Life has not left me much time in
> recent months to do much with Read_Alphabet.  I am trying to correct
> that to some degree now.  I am still having a little trouble with my
> e-mail -- my network at my office is not currently operational -- so
> do not despair if I do not respond to an e-mail as quickly as you
> would have liked.  I will respond eventually.
>
> I have been using Read's Alphabet, AKA Quikscript,for roughly 26
> years.  I have only had an e-mail from one other person who has been
> aware of the alphabet for that length of time, and he seems to
> alternate between Read's Alphabet and Shavian.  If you or anyone you
> know of has been using it for an extended period of time, let us hear
> from you.
>
> I am a firm believer in the utility of Read's Alphabet as well as its
> viability as an alternative alphabet that could help people in their
> daily lives just as Kingsley Read suggested in the Quikscript Manual.
>
> A little background on myself:  I am an attorney in private practice,
> who considers himself semi-computer literate.  By this I mean I am
> not knowledgable about specialized areas of computer science, such as
> designing fonts from scratch.  On the other hand, I am not afraid to
> open up my CPU to add hardware, and I remember what a DOS command
> is.  Hence, the semi-literate designation.  I bring this up because
> there are computer skills that I do not have, nor do I have the time
> to learn them in the near future, that would greatly enhance this
> site.  I do not doubt there are people in this group who already
> possess some of these skills and who, with a modest investment of
> time, could help us to turn this site into an attractive spot to
> attract more Read's Alphabet users.
>
> To give you some idea of what I am talking about:  Here are several
> things I would like to see appear on this site.
> 1.  A copy of the Quikscript manual.  It is not copyrighted so there
> is no legal prohibition I am aware of that would prevent us from
> posting it.
> 2.  Texts written in Read's Alphabet.  These should be varying
> lengths and levels of complexity.  They could be original or copies
> of literary works in the public domain.
> 3.  A practice area for people to write back and forth to each other
> in Read's Alphabet to gain experience in reading other people's
> script.  I must admit that even after years of occasional use, I am
> not as fluent at reading Read's Alphabet as I am at reading roman. 
> Practice makes perfect, after all.  I read roman everyday.  I cannot
> say that about Read's Alphabet.  It is hard to get practice when the
> only person that knows the script is yourself.  I know by experience,
> it is not easy to get casual acquaintances to learn Read's Alphabet,
> but the internet gives us the chance to reach people from around the
> globe who are intellectually curious.  The internet gives us an
> inexpensive platform that could spread the word to others.
> 4.  Have all explanatory notes written in both roman and Read's
> Alphabet just as Androcles was printed in roman and Shavian.
>
> For computer use we have the "Jerome" font, which was created about
> fifteen months ago.  I am excited about this as it gives us the
> opportunity to use the half-letters, which I found such an
> interesting facet of Read's Alphabet in handwriting as they provide
> word shapes that are more distinctive than those written with the
> full letters as in Junior Quikscript.  Jerome lets us use this
> feature in internet correspondence and teaching.  Jerome also shows
> that the letters can be joined in a "cursive" manner even
> in "printing" and remain graceful and attractive as opposed to the 
> detached and stilted Shavian.
>
> On the other hand, Jerome was the work of a person new to computer
> fonts, and it is not perfect.  I am confident that someone familiar
> with computer fonts could redesign Jerome to improve it and make it
> even easier to use while maintaining its basic style.  I believe some
> of the letters need additional work to bring them closer to their
> appearance in the Quikscript manual.  Another problem is that
> sometimes the cursor position does not appear where the next letter
> will be inserted.  This can be confusing.  And why does it only
> happen sometimes?  I think this problem is related to the use of half-
> letters, but I am not sure of this.
>
> I am interested in hearing your thoughts on this and any other
> matters connected to the use and spread of Read's Alphabet.  Thanks
> for taking the time to read this long post.
>
>
> Paige Gabhart
>
>
>
>
>
>

> Read_Alphabet-unsubscribe@egroups.com
>
>

<DIV><FONT face=3DArial size=3D2>Hey, everyone=
, I'm still here.  Paige, now how 
can you forget a last name like Zuc=
k.  It's as American as apple pie.  
(Er, as German as Bratwurst!=
)  Seriously, it's nice to see the Alphabet 
generating some discussio=
n again.. I'm still interested in crazy writing 
systems, and but have been=
 mostly studying shorthands...Regarding the problems 
with the Jerome font,=
 I still don't know why in some applications the cursor 
behaves so strange=
ly.  </FONT></DIV>
<DIV><FONT face=3DArial size=3D2></FONT> </DIV=
>
<DIV><FONT face=3DArial size=3D2></FONT> </DIV>
<DIV><FONT face=3DAr=
ial size=3D2></FONT> </DIV>
<DIV>Shalom v'Tovah,</DIV>
<DIV><FONT face=
=3DArial size=3D2></FONT> </DIV>
<DIV>Jon  <BR><A 
href=3D"http:/=
/surf.to/frimmin">http://surf.to/frimmin</A></DIV>
<DIV><FONT face=3DArial =
size=3D2></FONT> </DIV>
<DIV>It is more necessary to love much than to=
 think much;<BR>always do that 
which impels you most to love.</DIV>
<DIV><=
FONT face=3DArial size=3D2></FONT> </DIV>
<DIV>   &nbsp=
;    --St. Teresa of Avila, The 
Interior Castle</DIV>

  face=3D"Times New Roman" color=3D#000000><FONT size=3D3>I'll talk about =

12.0pt">I=92m

ied down. So it was

s=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle18><FONT face=3DArial color=3Dnavy 
 =
   size=3D2><SPAN 
    style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; mso-bi=
di-font-size: 12.0pt">I=92ve

kscript will improve my skills a bit

"FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt">In 
    r=
esponse to some of Paige=92s comments, I have fooled around making some ver=

r

e

n.

lass=3DMsoNormal><SPAN class=3DEmailStyle18><FONT face=3DArial color=3Dnavy=

T-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Arial; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt">Paige,

an you tell me which characters you think are malformed? I could have a go =

    at improving them - - - but please do not get your hopes very high. Wh=
oever 
    made Jerome is better at making fonts than I am.</SPAN></FONT></=
SPAN></P><![if !supportEmptyParas]>

al color=3Dnavy

    style=3D"FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAM=
ILY: Arial; mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt">If 
    anyone would care to, I=92d=

m running together. I do this by going to 
    Word=92s<o:p></o:p></SPAN></=
FONT></SPAN></P>

    <P class=3DMsoNormal style=3D"MARGIN-LEFT: 0.5in"><TT><FONT fac=
e=3D"Courier New"

    style=3D"FONT-SIZE=
: 10pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: 'Courier New'">Hi</SPAN></FONT></TT><FON=
T 
    face=3D"Courier New" color=3Dblack size=3D2><SPAN 
    style=3D"FONT=
-SIZE: 10pt; COLOR: black; FONT-FAMILY: 'Courier New'; mso-fareast-font-fam=
ily: 'Courier New'"><BR><TT>I 
    saw your message.  I know both Shaw=
s and Kwikskript but have not seen 
    any Kwikskrit on internet.  I =
would appreciate you letting me know if 
    there is.  Like you I hav=
e not had much opportunity to read it and that 
    is as important as writ=
ing it.  One way is by letter and I tried 
    somewhat to promote tha=
t but no one was interested.  Like you I am not 
    software savvy an=
d have no idea how to make up a page for Kwikskript.  
    Please keep=
 in touch if anyone is capable of doing something in this 
    area.</TT><B=
R><BR><TT>Sid</TT><BR><BR><BR><TT>On Mon, 11 February 2002, 
    "pgabhart"=
 wrote:</TT><BR><BR><TT>> </TT><BR><TT>> Welcome to all new 
    memb=
ers of the group and hello again to those who </TT><BR><TT>> have 
    b=
een members for awhile.  Life has not left me much time in 
    </TT><=
BR><TT>> recent months to do much with Read_Alphabet.  I am 
    tr=
ying to correct </TT><BR><TT>> that to some degree now.  I am 
    =
still having a little trouble with my </TT><BR><TT>> e-mail -- my networ=
k 
    at my office is not currently operational -- so </TT><BR><TT>> do=
 not 
    despair if I do not respond to an e-mail as quickly as you </TT><=
BR><TT>> 
    would have liked.  I will respond eventually.</TT><BR=
><TT>> 
    </TT><BR><TT>> I have been using Read's Alphabet, AKA Qui=
kscript,for 
    roughly 26 </TT><BR><TT>> years.  I have only had =
an e-mail from one 
    other person who has been </TT><BR><TT>> aware o=
f the alphabet for that 
    length of time, and he seems to </TT><BR><TT>&=
gt; alternate between Read's 
    Alphabet and Shavian.  If you or any=
one you </TT><BR><TT>> know of 
    has been using it for an extended pe=
riod of time, let us hear 
    </TT><BR><TT>> from you.</TT><BR><TT>>=
 </TT><BR><TT>> I am a firm 
    believer in the utility of Read's Alpha=
bet as well as its </TT><BR><TT>> 
    viability as an alternative alpha=
bet that could help people in their 
    </TT><BR><TT>> daily lives just=
 as Kingsley Read suggested in the 
    Quikscript Manual.</TT><BR><TT>>=
 </TT><BR><TT>> A little background on 
    myself:  I am an attorn=
ey in private practice, </TT><BR><TT>> who 
    considers himself semi-c=
omputer literate.  By this I mean I am 
    </TT><BR><TT>> not know=
ledgable about specialized areas of computer 
    science, such as </TT><BR=
><TT>> designing fonts from scratch.  On 
    the other hand, I am =
not afraid to </TT><BR><TT>> open up my CPU to add 
    hardware, and I =
remember what a DOS command </TT><BR><TT>> is.  
    Hence, the sem=
i-literate designation.  I bring this up because 
    </TT><BR><TT>&gt=
; there are computer skills that I do not have, nor do I 
    have the time=
 </TT><BR><TT>> to learn them in the near future, that would 
    greatl=
y enhance this </TT><BR><TT>> site.  I do not doubt there are 
    =
people in this group who already </TT><BR><TT>> possess some of these 
 =
   skills and who, with a modest investment of </TT><BR><TT>> time, coul=
d 
    help us to turn this site into an attractive spot to </TT><BR><TT>&g=
t; 
    attract more Read's Alphabet users.</TT><BR><TT>> </TT><BR><TT>&=
gt; To 
    give you some idea of what I am talking about:  Here are s=
everal 
    </TT><BR><TT>> things I would like to see appear on this 
  =
  site.</TT><BR><TT>> 1.  A copy of the Quikscript manual.  It=
 is 
    not copyrighted so there </TT><BR><TT>> is no legal prohibition=
 I am 
    aware of that would prevent us from </TT><BR><TT>> posting 
 =
   it.</TT><BR><TT>> 2.  Texts written in Read's Alphabet.  Th=
ese 
    should be varying </TT><BR><TT>> lengths and levels of complexi=
ty.  
    They could be original or copies </TT><BR><TT>> of litera=
ry works in the 
    public domain.</TT><BR><TT>> 3.  A practice ar=
ea for people to write 
    back and forth to each other </TT><BR><TT>> =
in Read's Alphabet to gain 
    experience in reading other people's </TT><=
BR><TT>> script.  I must 
    admit that even after years of occasi=
onal use, I am </TT><BR><TT>> not as 
    fluent at reading Read's Alpha=
bet as I am at reading roman.  
    </TT><BR><TT>> Practice makes p=
erfect, after all.  I read roman 
    everyday.  I cannot </TT><B=
R><TT>> say that about Read's 
    Alphabet.  It is hard to get pra=
ctice when the </TT><BR><TT>> only 
    person that knows the script is =
yourself.  I know by experience, 
    </TT><BR><TT>> it is not easy=
 to get casual acquaintances to learn Read's 
    Alphabet, </TT><BR><TT>&g=
t; but the internet gives us the chance to reach 
    people from around th=
e </TT><BR><TT>> globe who are intellectually 
    curious.  The in=
ternet gives us an </TT><BR><TT>> inexpensive 
    platform that could s=
pread the word to others.</TT><BR><TT>> 4.  
    Have all explanato=
ry notes written in both roman and Read's 
    </TT><BR><TT>> Alphabet j=
ust as Androcles was printed in roman and 
    Shavian.</TT><BR><TT>> </=
TT><BR><TT>> For computer use we have the 
    "Jerome" font, which was =
created about </TT><BR><TT>> fifteen months 
    ago.  I am excited=
 about this as it gives us the </TT><BR><TT>> 
    opportunity to use th=
e half-letters, which I found such an </TT><BR><TT>> 
    interesting fa=
cet of Read's Alphabet in handwriting as they provide 
    </TT><BR><TT>&gt=
; word shapes that are more distinctive than those written 
    with the </=
TT><BR><TT>> full letters as in Junior Quikscript.  
    Jerome let=
s us use this </TT><BR><TT>> feature in internet correspondence 
    and=
 teaching.  Jerome also shows </TT><BR><TT>> that the letters can 
=
    be joined in a "cursive" manner even </TT><BR><TT>> in "printing" an=
d 
    remain graceful and attractive as opposed to the  </TT><BR><TT>=
> 
    detached and stilted Shavian.</TT><BR><TT>> </TT><BR><TT>> =
On the 
    other hand, Jerome was the work of a person new to computer 
  =
  </TT><BR><TT>> fonts, and it is not perfect.  I am confident that=
 
    someone familiar </TT><BR><TT>> with computer fonts could redesign=
 Jerome 
    to improve it and make it </TT><BR><TT>> even easier to use=
 while 
    maintaining its basic style.  I believe some </TT><BR><TT>=
> of the 
    letters need additional work to bring them closer to their=
 </TT><BR><TT>> 
    appearance in the Quikscript manual.  Another =
problem is that 
    </TT><BR><TT>> sometimes the cursor position does n=
ot appear where the 
    next letter </TT><BR><TT>> will be inserted.&nb=
sp; This can be 
    confusing.  And why does it only </TT><BR><TT>&gt=
; happen 
    sometimes?  I think this problem is related to the use o=
f 
    half-</TT><BR><TT>> letters, but I am not sure of this.</TT><BR><=
TT>>

this and any
